main_definition: Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) is a core protocol of the Internet Protocol Suite that ensures reliable, ordered, and error-checked delivery of data between network devices.

meanings_and_examples.definition: A transport layer protocol in computer networking
meanings_and_examples.example: When sending files over the internet, TCP is used to ensure they arrive intact.
The TTL field in a packet decreases with each hop in an IP network due to time-to-live (TCP).

meanings_and_examples.definition: A term used in computing and networking, but not directly related to TCP itself
meanings_and_examples.example: In the context of computer systems, 'tcp' might be mentioned as a piece of technical jargon.

meanings_and_examples.definition: An error or misunderstanding related to network protocols (though this is an incorrect use of the term)
meanings_and_examples.example: If someone says they encountered a problem with their TCP connection, it means there was a disruption in data transmission.

additional_definitions.definition: A reliable and ordered delivery protocol that forms the backbone of internet communication
additional_definitions.example: Websites use TCP to ensure every byte of information, like HTML code or images, is delivered correctly.

additional_definitions.definition: An integral part of networking that allows computers to communicate effectively by handling data transmission errors and ensuring packets arrive in sequence
additional_definitions.example: When streaming a video online, TCP helps maintain smooth playback without interruptions or loss of quality.
